questiontext.text:
Exercise

A worn, poorly set-up machine is observed to produce components whose length \(X\) follows a normal distribution with mean \({@mu@}\text{cm}\) and variance \({@var@}\text{cm}^2\). Calculate, to 4 decimal places:

  1. the probability that a component is at least \({@numa@}\text{cm}\) long: [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. the probability that the length of a component lies between \({@numc@}\text{cm}\) and \({@numb@}\text{cm}\): [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
Solution

Let \(X\) be the random variable for the length of the component produced by the machine, then \(X \sim N({@mu@}, {@var@})\). The standardised Normal distribution \(Z \sim N(0,1)\) is obtained through the transformation \(Z = \dfrac{X - {@mu@}}{\sqrt{{@var@}}} = \dfrac{X - {@mu@}}{{@sd@}}\).

  1. The first stage is to transform the probability with respect to the standard Normal random variable: \[\text{P}(X \geq {@numa@}) = \text{P}\left(\dfrac{X - {@mu@}}{{@sd@}} \geq \dfrac{{@numa@} - {@mu@}}{{@sd@}}\right) = \text{P}(Z \geq {@zscorea@}).\]

    Next, transform the probability so that we can use the standard Normal table: \[\text{P}(Z \geq {@zscorea@}) = 1 - \text{P}(Z < {@zscorea@}) = 0.5 - \text{P}(0  < Z < {@zscorea@}).\]

    Reading this value from the table obtains the required probability to be \(\text{P}(X \geq {@numa@}) = 0.5 - {@displaydp(enta,4)@} = {@displaydp(ta1,4)@}\) to 4 decimal places.

  2. Again, the first stage is to standardise the probability: \[ \begin{align} \text{P}({@numc@} < X < {@numb@}) & = \text{P}\left(\dfrac{{@numc@} - {@mu@}}{{@sd@}} < \dfrac{X - {@mu@}}{{@sd@}} < \dfrac{{@numb@} - {@mu@}}{{@sd@}}\right) \\ & = \text{P}({@zscorec@} < Z < {@zscoreb@}). \end{align}\]

    Note that this probability is symmetric around the mean of \(0\), so: \[\text{P}({@zscorec@} < Z < {@zscoreb@}) = 2 \times \text{P}(0 < Z < {@zscoreb@}).\]

    The value for \({@zscoreb@}\) is not in the standard Normal table, but it is the mid-point between \({@displaydp(zscoreb-0.005,2)@}\) and \({@displaydp(zscoreb+0.005,2)@}\). So an approximate of this probability is:

    \[\text{P}(0 < Z < {@zscoreb@}) \approx \dfrac{{@displaydp(entb1,4)@}+{@displaydp(entb2,4)@}}{2}.\]

    Using this value, the required probability is approximated to be: \(\text{P}({@numc@} < X < {@numb@}) \approx 2 \times \dfrac{{@entb1@}+{@entb2@}}{2} = {@displaydp(ta2,4)@}\)to 4 decimal places.

    When using a statistical calculator, a more accurate calculation of the probability returns \(\text{P}({@numc@} < X < {@numb@}) = {@displaydp(EXACTta2,4)@} \) to 4 decimal places.

questionvariables.text: mu:20 var:2.56 sd:sqrt(var) zscorea:decimalplaces(rand_with_step(1.1,2.9,0.1),1) numa:decimalplaces(mu+(zscorea*sd),2) zscoreb:decimalplaces(rand_with_step(0.375,1.375,0.05),3) numb:decimalplaces(mu+(zscoreb*sd),2) zscorec:-zscoreb numc:decimalplaces(mu+(zscorec*sd),2) enta:decimalplaces(float(cdf_normal(zscorea,0,1)-0.5),4); entb1:decimalplaces(float(cdf_normal(zscoreb-0.005,0,1)-0.5),4); entb2:decimalplaces(float(cdf_normal(zscoreb+0.005,0,1)-0.5),4); ta1:decimalplaces(float(0.5-enta),4) ta2:decimalplaces(float(2*(entb1+(0.5*(entb2-entb1)))),4) EXACTta2: decimalplaces(float(cdf_normal(numb, mu, sd) - cdf_normal(numc, mu, sd)),4);
